author: Erika S.

description: I was lured by the smell of chai on a cold winter night. I was served masala chai from a giant copper pot. All the signs were pointing towards a great cup of chai but I was disappointed. Being Indian, I have high standards for chai and this cup did not match by expectation or the atmosphere. I found the taste to be slightly bitter as though it was over-brewed and I could not decipher any spice. Maybe I just had a bad experience that day but I did not think it was worth the $4 cup for chai.
author: Sharmila C.

description: This place has amazing tea. Would be 5 stars but prices are extremely high. Some teas cost up to $11. Having said that the chai can not be beat. Overall, it's a great place to have a tea and maybe a snack. I think it's hard to compete with four barrel which is next door but go here for chai.
author: Olivia G.

description: Ginseng Apple tea was so yummy. Great place to relax and study! Staff is very friendly!
author: Xavier W.

description:
I love tea - absolutely adore it, and Samovar Tea caters brilliantly to any tea connoisseur 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

Samovar Tea is a wonderfully exciting blend of traditional tea house and lab of a mad scientist; with massive cauldrons of tea constantly being blended and added to by masters of their craft who are more than happy to share their wisdom with customers. It's fresh, it's comfortable, and very well executed. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

The recent resurrection of the tea-specific shop has lead to a somewhat unsettling increase in the price of tea these days, and nowhere is that more clear than here at Samovar Tea. I almost did a literal double-take when I realized that my large Masala Chai was pricing out to $5.50, and while this was a generous portion (at least two cups if not two and a half), that's a pretty stupid price point irrespective of the blend of spices that comes attached to the tea. Samovar sits right on the fence of rational pricing here, and while the price wasn't enough to deter me from coming back - it was close. Star Granted, reluctantly. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

I like the bite of Masala Chai tea, but oh my goodness did this have some serious bite. As in, holy moly let me take a quick break from drinking this before I get some serious indigestion here. That doesn't mean it was at all bad, but unless you're really a fan of Masala Chai you might want to stick with something a bit safer (I'd equate this to a strong IPA in the beer world). Single Star Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

As a tea nerd, I love the concept of Samovar Tea, and I'm glad it's popular, but on account of the price point and the product, I can't say I would strongly recommend it to friends unless I was 100% sure they were as crazy about tea as I am. No Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description:
Like this place needs another great review. I seem to constantly need tire patches or new tires and this is my go to spot while waiting for my car to be worked on. 

The matcha latte is just right and I love that they always have samples of teas to try. The turmeric coconut latte is also a great option when you're not needing the caffeine. 

I've also enjoyed their toasts--overpriced, but what isn't in this city? The gluten free matcha mochi really hit the spot this morning.
author: dena r.

description: Get a vegan chai, any of their toasts, and a mini mochi cake to go. One of my favorite places in SF. The chai is authentic and cooked in copper pots too!
author: Kartik S.

description:
I live close by and my nose often leads me here because of the incredible scents that spill out of this tiny shop. My favorite thing to get is the Rose-infused Arnold Palmer. It's refreshing and absolutely delicious! 

The seating here is pretty unique and hipster I might add. There are large steps to sit on or a bench outside. If you're looking for more of a "sit down" spot I'd try their union square location. 

Definitely worth trying if you're in the Mission!
author: Kelly F.

description: The tea here is great but seriously the wait is unnecessarily long when it's busy. I understand it gets busy but it's annoying when the cashier is taking their time and having small talk with everybody.
author: Lian D.

description: I love Samovar's Yerba Buena location (one of my favorite places to eat in SF), but I mostly come to the Valencia location for chai or, lately, their boba (the chai version and the Hong Kong milk tea version). Their chai is legendary and rightfully so. Very consistent here with what we expect from their other locations (hooray for tasty proper chai). Their boba, though, now that I've had it a few times, is sadly not awesome. I'll only go to boba places that actually brew tea so that part is obviously wonderful here. But the boba itself is always too hard and that's become a turn-off. Only came here this week for boba because Boba Guys is closed temporarily. Will come to this Samovar in the future only for chai and their delicious snacks (fat toast, mochi muffins, etc). A beautiful little space to sit on a day when the sun streams in and you can perch for a few sips in their funky seating area.
author: Shawna S.

description:
5 star experience: incredible service, beautiful zen atmosphere, wifi. wish there were tables

4.5 stars quality, curated teas of all types, free samples, and top-notch avocado toast.

* Matcha - Unsweetened matcha shots, hard to come by. Pretty good, but only for the purists because it is really grassy when unsweetened. 
* Masala Chai  ($4.75) - Very drinkable, slightly sweet and spicy, perfect balanced. Comes in almond or whole variations.
* Avocado truffle toast on brioche ($9) - Light fluffy brioche loaf (similar to Boba Guys') with a strong scent of truffle salt and a WHOLE avocado. Yes, a whole avocado. It's topped with a perfectly  poached egg and microgreens. Probably one of the best avocado toasts in the city!
author: Jess C.

description: Great chai, but they are soooo slow. No reason to create a line. The chai is already made. You just have to pour it in a cup and that takes them good 5-10 minute.
author: L B.

description: There really aren't enough tea rooms in SF, and I'm always on the hunt for them! Samovar Tea Room is incredibly aesthetically pleasing with their beautiful tea pots and decor. They have a huge selection of decaf and caffeinated teas which is great for when I'm craving a warm cup in the evening but also want to attempt falling asleep in an hour or two. Instantly when you enter the shop, you are wafted with the smell of exotic and herbal teas from India. It's a quite small location, with minimal seating compared to the other locations. The chamomile blossom, ryokucha, and Iron Goddess are my favorites with a hint of honey and almond milk. Love this place and wish there were more tea lounges!
author: Lisa H.

description: Expansive tea selection - all quality! The teas I've really enjoyed are the turmeric & HK style. They offer almond milk as well. Be prepared to pay about $5 for a tea beverage! The wait isn't too long to order but for a specialty beverage, it can take about 5 minutes to get your tea (brew time dependent).
author: Stephanie C.

description:
We stumbled on this little jewel.  We were lured in by the aroma of spice.

Inside, the decor uses rough hewn wood, light, texture of unfinished marble slabs, to compliment their products.

We ordered simply Masala Chai and were not disappointed.

The seating on the side is basically stone bleachers.  The bathroom requires a pin code.  

Inspite of the small space you didn't feel crowded and no rush to leave as the afternoon edged toward dusk.

A lovely way to spend some time in.
author: S P.

description:
I'm a big tea fan and have been wanting to try Samsovar.  I wanted something simple and got the Hong Kong Latte.  I definitely want to try the matcha and chai next time cause the HK latte was good but not overly impressive.  The seating is kind of awkward and limited, so I don't really recommend planning to do work here.  I don't really get a friendly vibe from this place either.  Seemed like it was all business and no customer connection.    

Everyone has raved about Samovar, so I am willing to come back again and try something else.  Until then, I'm not sure what the hype is about.
author: Lyn C.

description:
As someone who recently had to quit coffee, this place makes tea exciting. Not only is the tea bar ridiculously well-designed and serene, it's really fun watching the baristas (is this the right term??) make drinks with all the glass contraptions! I feel like I'm in a hipster chem class! 

I'm particularly partial to their matcha tea latte and turmeric spice tea. I'm also grateful for all the gluten-free goodies they have behind the counter - especially the matcha mochi cake. 

All in all, a great rest stop while wandering around the Mission!
author: Kathy O.

description: Went here this morning looking for some good tea and relaxing ambiance.  Walked up to find a small, uninviting space with hard slab seating, no cushions and a few tiny tables. Asked for advice on a good herbal coffee substitute. Got the response "umm."  The other employee overheard and suggested matcha.  Fine, not what i had in mind but i like matcha.  Asked for miso soup.  They were out of it (at 10am).  Asked for the tea soup - "umm, let me see if we have ingredients."  Dont worry about it, ill just take an avocado toast.  Asked for bathroom code only to find no toilet paper and no paper towels.  Came out for my tea and toast, toast didnt get charged or made.  2 stars for tea selection and outdoor seating option.  Im sure it was just an off day but definitely dont come to this location expecting Samovar's self proclaimed "urban sanctuary" experience or to get what you pay for with Samovar's prices as it is really just a place to pick up tea to go.
author: Shannon L.

description: Wonderful chai. Decor is clean and modern. Outside seating to enjoy the Mission District sun. Avocado toast is delicious!
author: Katherine B.

description: I love their chai. It's spicy and warm, but not too sweet. They have fantastic teas, too. I just wish they had a little more options to nosh on when I stop by at breakfast time. But that's not their shtick--they do tea and they do it well.
author: Charlotte A.

description: Like the ambience. They serve diff kinds of teas and food. I had the chai bc I can smell that from the sidewalk.  Chai is spicy and flavorful. The chai is pre made and served hot.
author: Gloria T.

description:
Incredibly addicted to afternoon masala chai tea with Mochi green tea cake.   There's something incredibly comforting about hot afternoon tea when you just want to break free from the hum drum of a 9-5 job- my 15 minute pm break consists of a 5 minute walk to Samovar with an escapist like myself - complain about the J-O-B and its miserable confines. The masala chai is readily made in a silver urn-like container with a choice between whole or almond milk-with ice or w/o. It's a quick to-go pick-me-up process. There is an extensive list of exotic and not-so exotic tea drinks, which does not interest me - but might peak yours. To go with this delightful chai tea is a nice selection of Mochi  tea cakes- I love these  little pieces of delightful cakes- there's a spongy and bouncy texture that I truly enjoy - a bit in the expensive side but so worth it. They also serve tea sandwiches looks good but have not tried it. 
If you have the time- enjoy your tea in the parklet located outside of samovar or inside if it's not too packed.
author: Michelle B.

description: Interesting place, definitely worth a visit. Watching them make a dish is pretty entertaining too.
author: Daisy S.

description: Love it! Hi-Tech system to brew tea, combine traditional tea with professional hi-tech, very good experience
author: Faye L.

description:
TL;DR - Amazing tea. Not spacious like the Yerba Buena location, but the teas are treats are definitely still as tasty!

I always go to matcha and they do it the best here, so..... yes; get it get it.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Really a nice place to relax after a tough week and the food and drink are really good as well~
author: Shelley W.

description:
Interesting remake of the Samovar lounges.  The concrete walls and layout, fits the urban feel and Mission district that this Samovar is located in!  Not much of a comfortable lounge area, however.  I was impressed with their bathroom that had a motion sensored sink and a blow dryer as well with the sink!  Pretty neat!

I like their chemist tubes as container tea making!

I love Samovar's tea selections!  It is refreshing and charming for what it is!  I prefer their other locations, where you can lounge in an open aired environment!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Stumbled upon Samovar while walking through the mission. I had already drank some coffee at Four Barrel but the wonderful aroma lured me inside. The masala chai was on point as was the decor. I'd definitely recommend this spot to friends.
author: Dylan A.

description: Oh man, I miss this place. I just moved out of SF and let's just say, I would kill for one of their Chai's right now! Their Chai has just the right amount of spices but what I truly appreciated is that it wasn't sickly sweet the way a lot of others are. Their mochi mini-cakes are quite delightful as well. However, do prepare for pretentious service from some employees, and it's definitely expensive. Oh, and don't go after yoga class ends - all the yoga people go there after their class, it seems like. :)
author: Phil l.

description:
The food is not bad when it comes to you when hot not semi-warm.  Service is tremendously bad.......dishes that was ordered is just sitting on the kitchen counter......I guess that is why dish was Luke warm.   When finished, you would think someone would come to clean off the table after
Ten minutes.......For such a TEA place (hi-end).......surprise!!!!!!!= disappointment .    Especially when wait staff just standing around chatting.
author: Cassandra O.

description:
I'm a fan of this Samovar location, which is different from the teahouse/lounge Samovars around the city. While I enjoy the tea and the ambiance that Samovar lounges offer, I always thought they were overpriced.

Enter Samovar Tea on Valencia Street. I love the sleek, urban decor of this location, coupled with the lab equipments they use to make the tea. Sure, it's likely a marketing strategy, but it doesn't detract from feeling like a fun space. 

The price of the tea here is also lower than other Samovars, and they recently started offering "Eggs & Things" as part of their menu, which includes delicious options like sous vide eggs, avocado, toast, and oh-so-hip mason jar rice dishes. Healthy, delicious, and more reasonably priced than other Samovar lounges. 

There aren't that many places to sit but you can still grab a seat by the wall and watch the tea masters craft your drinks and food. All in all, I love it.
author: Kate M.

description:
I realized while writing another review I had never reviewed one of my go-to tea places when I'm in Valencia.

To start off with, I pretty much love everything about this place. The wait line is never exceedingly long, the service is always friendly, and their bathroom is just gorgeous - though that seems like a strange thing to rate them on.

And their tea. Because that's what they do. Tea. It's the perfect drinking temperature, perfectly steeped and perfectly served. The flavors are such a nice bouquet that you want to sit there drinking forever. But you can't... because... Life.

Honestly, I also really love their bench system. It's very spa like without the crowded noise of chairs or tables. It adds to the relaxation I find in this place. Simply drinking a cup of tea.
author: Meg T.

description: I really liked the minimalist interior; simple and clean, long bench with small tables, and really nice servers. I am a lover of matcha tea so i ordered a matcha latte with almond milk. They made it nice and strong, and I enjoyed it immensely. Had to remove a star for the price point; $5.00 is rather over priced.
author: Mei W.

description: Pumpkin Chai is where its at! The lady working the register said it was very "squashy" and she was right. Whereas Starbucks pumpkin-anything has a sort-of artifical taste, Samovar is truly authentic pumpkin.  I got mine with almond milk! Also, FYI, there are jars of tea sitting on the counter right next to the register....do not pick them up or try to smell them like you would at a normal tea shop. I got a little chastising for thinking they were there for customers to smell! In my defense, move the tea jars off the front counter!!
author: Hayley H.

description:
The Chai is fantastic and the people and service here is always very good; however, the small Chai went from being 12 oz to what looks like 6? It's the same price (an already baffling $4!) and its teeny! I can't afford to tip on a $4 Dixie cup! I can't afford this Chai! 

I'm not an anti hipster/anti techy/ SF-hater (call me naive, but I still believe in the good soul of SF) but I am sorely disappointed in Samovar. This is either greed or their business is struggling. If it's the latter, better consider scrimping somewhere else. This makes you look pretty bad.
author: Melissa M.

description:
This location is so different from the others! Less of a Japanese zen garden vibe, more of a bare minimalist vibe with accents of concrete. They also don't serve food here, so it's a much smaller 

They also play up the 'science' of tea-making with these fancy machines that look like chemistry lab sets.

* Chai - 4.5 stars
The chai is really great - they make this in bulk, and you can see them add all the spices to these heavy duty clay (I think) pots. The flavor is much more authentic than your typical local coffee shop chai. More spicy, more clove-y. 

* Matcha shot ($3.50) - 2 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/samovar-tea-san-francisco-2?select=O57PiSQ07ag5xihO6dZg_w#O57PiSQ07ag5xihO6dZg_w
This was honestly pretty gross. I like green tea, I drink pretty bitter stuff from China at home, but this just tasted like rotted, powdered seaweed. I had my friends try it and they felt the same. Also definitely not worth $3.50 (and I was trying to save money).
author: Ziyan C.

description: You can smell the chai walking up to the place from a block away practically! I had their green tea and it was legit. For those with almond or dairy allergies, though, you're out of luck- all of their chai teas have one or the other in it. No regular chai tea, either, which was surprising. Oh, and it's expensive. BUT you're in SF and you get what you pay for ;).
author: Rob M.

description:
If you're in a hurry and in need of a great quality pick me up...you've stopped by the perfect joint. 

I'm in love with the chai tea latte. It's already made with milk. You can have your choice of almond or regular. Either way you can't go wrong. So rich, so creamy, so caffeinated! Just how I like it! 

There's an assortment of teas to choose from. Sometimes even a yelp check in offer. The staff is friendly and will help guide you in the right direction if you aren't sure what to order. (My hubby needed some guidance) 

There are small bites to eat. 
Nice area for lounging. 
And beautiful artwork out front. 
Best of all; the bathroom is clean!!!!!!!
author: Alyssa P.

description:
Came here and had the Turmeric tea latte which was delicious and I can't wait til I find myself in the mission again so that I can get my hands on another one (I make my own at home so it is definitely saying something).  

Only thing keeping them from getting 5 stars is the limited milk selection (almond or whole) and no real seating to relax for any period of time.
author: Adele T.

description: All drinks are fabulous but they recently changed their Mochi cake recipe. A real bummer because they used to be moist and full of flavor but now they are dry and inedible.
author: Kate W.

description: This place is a unique tea house.  Everyone there seems really "cultured" and hip.  They have comfy front booths that you can reserve.  However, $14 for some almond milk and matcha powder?!  Tasty but ridiculous.  I'm very surprised this place can stay in business, I guess that's San Franciscans for ya!
author: Mia N.

description: Very cool concept and the people were super friendly, I just wasn't a big fan of their version of vegan chai. Maybe too spicy or just a different sort of spice I'm not a fan of? However they have lots of great teas and their egg toasts looked amazing so I would try this place again and get something different!
author: Kiki H.

description:
Been here twice for Chai. 

The first time, after we purchased Chai tea, we witnessed 2 female employees trying to figure out how to get rid of flies in the pastry display case. They didn't throw the pastries away. Barf. Out.

Decided to give these guys a second chance. My friend had Chai tea and got crazy bad food poisoning. On her birthday. That's all sorts of foul.

Never again.
author: Gabriela W.

description: Their avocado toast is heaven!!!!!!! The place itself is also pretty cool with a very modern vibe. I got my toast to go but if I am ever in town I will definitely return to try some of their tea selection!
author: Maria P.

description: Samovar takes their tea seriously. Their matcha cold brew and their chai tea are no joke - probably the strongest / most intense I've had! You can even see the giant vats of chai tea brewing right next to the cash register. I love coming back here to try the different drinks on their menu, especially since they have multiple different matcha ones! The matcha shake is a good option if you're looking for something sweet (it's not actually a shake though, more like a latte which I found kind of confusing), while the matcha cold brew is great if you're looking for a strong pick me up (and comes in a mason jar!). You can also pick up some of their loose leaf teas there as well, and a concentrate of their chai tea!
author: Stephany L.

description: Visited here for the first time. Got the turmeric coconut milk chai- while it was wholesome and nutritious, I have to say I think it had too much turmeric and ginger for my tastes. I think lighter on the roots would make for a more light, refreshing tea in the middle of the day. Ambiance was lovely though (the steel pots that they make the chai in were gorgeous and authentic, being im from South Asia) and the cashier was super friendly!
author: Melissa D.

description:
Hmm I felt a little overwhelmed, but perhaps this was my own fault since I'm a bit of a tea purist and I got the Velvet Cacao which had so many things going on it, I'm not even sure what I really ended up drinking. So yeah, feeling a little meh about it but very possible that I ordered the wrong thing. 

That being said, the vibe here is pretty cool. Samovar makes tea cool the way that all the hipster cafes in the world have made coffee cool. They've got a scientist vibe going on in the store that reminds me a lot of Boba Guys -- lots of test tubes and beakers, etc. Although I think they might have predated Boba Guys but ANYWAYS I digress. They've got a menu that tells you what the teas are based off of, so I got a tea that was based off of pu-er because normally I like that stuff and then I chose the one with the word "cacao" because you know I like chocolate. Maybe it'd taste like chocolately tea or something. 

But no. I got... a mixture that tasted like coconut tea. Very confused. Maybe that's just what happens when you fuse things together. 

Anyways, not hating this place since obviously these people take their tea seriously and I'm kind of a noob and underappreciating their craft, but that being said, I wasn't a fan of the Velvet Cacao but would love to try a different variation in the future.

tldr; fancy af tea. if you know your tea you'll be impressed. if you don't (like me), you might mess up on ordering, so may tell the barista (do you call tea making people baristas?) your preferences and get something you like
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Amazing chai and toasts but only good if you have lots of time.  It does take a while to get your food even if you're just getting already prepared chai.

Today I ended up standing in line for five minutes and had to leave empty-handed because I was afraid it might take another five to get what I wanted .

I wish they had an express line for just getting a cup of chai...
author: Lorraine P.

description:
I want to come here every week after getting The Rebel at Craftsman and Wolves (see my other review). Hell, I want to just walk by this store front every day just to smell the spices simmered in milk. HEAVEN. It smells like the holidays.

The bag of spices in each pot is probably a 1 pound satchet....no skimping on flavor here. The chai itself has just enough heat from the spices to warm the back of your throat, and has a little bit of liquid delicious fat from cream/butter in the recipe. Doesn't that already sound delicious?

It's great on it's own, but I like to add a tablespoon of honey in there to really round out the flavors and get an extra bit of sweetness.

We also tried the Tumeric Latte, but I didn't like that very much. Tasted like potatoes to me...
author: Bonnie L.

description:
I LOVE going into this place. Specialty tea/coffee place! it's the whole experience where you get to see your drink being made from fresh... a bit expensive but worth it! think they are known for their Chai team, b/c everyone seems to be getting it! 

Place also gives calm energy unique flavor from Asia and simple decor! wish they would open up more locations and also improve the other location by movie theatre.
author: jess c.

description:
I don't really know what real chai tastes like but this place has me coming back time and time again, especially on chilly days when a cup of hot, hot chai is all that you want. Milky, spicy, not overly sweet. 

I recently discovered they serve food as well - whatever that truffle egg on toast dish is looks delicious, and all their other options really look too beautiful to even touch. Check out some of the photos and you'll see what I mean.
author: Jackie C.

description: Okay, so the vegan almond milk masala chai is killer. I admit to buying it multiple times. The peppermint sage herbal is also super nice, and several of there other made to order hot teas look lovely. The catch: WHOA EXPENSIVE. Not hardly a thing for vegans on their small food menu. I settled for the warm greens and rice and added avocado. $10 for probably the smallest scoop of rice and the saddest pile of wilted arugula you ever saw. They made it wrong by adding salmon (hey it happens). The girl working told me she would fix it again. I got half way through eating it and there were multiple flecks of salmon I had not previously detected. Meaning - all she did was pick it off. TOTALLY unprofessional and a huge disappointment to me or any vegan. I've also had some short tempered service here on many occasions. The place gets packed. But that's not a reason to be rude and short with customers.
author: Katie R.

description:
I would totally decorate my future home in the style of Samovar on Valencia.

Aside from that, I've burned my mouth on hot chai lattes to the point where it blisters and have been disappointed by lukewarm matcha lattes.

Taste - perfect. Not too sweet with well, the flavor of tea. Masala chai is fantastic.

Consistency? Completely lacking. In regards to service, temperature, AMOUNT of drink in my cup...

If you do stop by, do yourself a favor and don't order the Hong Kong tea. Literally your typical milk tea with a jasmine green tea blend that you could easily replicate elsewhere.
author: Colleen M.

description: Super tasty chai tea with different flavors and milk options  for  Great little spot to have a quick tea or snack.
author: Alfred K.

description:
So disappointed- it's a shame that the original Samovar on 18th is gone because this sad iteration does little to substitute what was. I have always loved the masala chai but what I got today was over-spiced as well as over-priced.
Nothing lasts.
author: J D.

description: really nice tea i had ever. The jasmine tea is the best for. Definetly i'll come back. also like white fancy paper cup
author: Oneworld O.

description: Beautiful atmosphere with delicious chai and great avocado toast. I'll definitely be coming back here! Would recommend.
author: Claire M.

description:
Swung by for a post-yoga treat with a friend and absolutely loved it. I'm on a 24-hour hipster toast diet (but actually) so Samovar fit the bill perfectly.

The avocado toast was pretty decadent, with the brioche toast slathered in butter or olive oil and topped with heaping chunks of avocado. I always feel avo toast without a spritz of lemon juice is a bit boring, so it was a little too simple for me but delicious nonetheless. Would be nice if Samovar offered topping options like feta.

We also tried the turmeric latte and Puerh teas and loved those as well. The overall Samovar menu looks delicious, can't wait to try everything else!
author: Anisha C.

description:
Nothing special about this place, I went in and asked for a Hong Kong milk tea. The person who helped me didn't actually know the way to make it, so he went to an iPad they have in the middle of the tea bar to check how to make a Hong Kong Milk tea. He took a lot of time to make it. Finally when I got my drink and had my first sip I found out that this drink didn't taste anything close to a Hong Kong Milk tea, I tasted like basil with tons of cheap green tea with heavy milk. 
The only reason I give this place 2 stars instead of 1 is because of the decoration inside the store.
author: H C.

description: Wouldn't let me order plain tea 15 minutes before they close when I waited 10 minutes in line. Tea place that doesn't sell tea? I've worked for the restaurant/hospitality(coffee shops) and other quick service for over almost 5 years and never would I deny a customer of making them something as simple as a plane tea. Ridiculous.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
REALNESS. Expensive realness.

You want a chai punch to the face? This is the spot. So freakin' spicy. Served from shiny copper vats (so sleek and puuuurdy). Ridiculously yum.

Want a pastry that isn't crazy sweet? Get the matcha mochi cake. I love the gummy mochi texture mixed with cakiness. Seriously, it's addicting.

And that almond milk. Like it came fresh from an almond's teat, if it had one.

Only downside: not a comfortable space to sit and hang, so just take your expensive goodies and go.
author: Kristine W.

description: I walked by and stopped due to the lovely fragrance. I adore tea so was interested in trying the menu. Unfortunately, the boy at the counter was unhelpful and wouldn't offer any. The reviews below mention that they were able to sample tumeric latte with both types of milk. Not in my case. I didn't want to risk getting something that was strong or distasteful. Unfortunately, they lost a potential customer.
author: Summer S.

description: Their Masala Chai is bomb. They recently expanded their mochi cake selection. Matcha, Black Sesame, and Yuzu Poppyseed are my go-tos.
author: Wayne S.

description:
I come here 5 days a week and the experience is always awesome. As a Japanese green tea snob, I can tell you the Green Ecstasy is better than 90% of the green tea you'll enjoy in Japan. In fact, all the teas here are top notch, whether caffeinated, milk-based (shout out to their Hong Kong milk tea!), iced, or all three. (Matcha latte, what?!)

In double fact, EVERYTHING here is awesome. The service is extremely friendly. Worried about that infamous San Francisco barista judgment. DON'T. The kind folks who work here are unfailingly friendly and informative. They also make a wicked avocado toast.

Come to Samovar and enjoy a little oasis from your hectic city life!

*One caveat: I think they changed the music lately and it's not quite as on point as before. Am I mistaken...?
author: Dan S.

description: Well hell. 15 dollar cuppa tea. If a restaurant could be a d ouch bag, or "that guy" , this would be it. The ambiance/decor says im a snob, and there isn't a decent seat in the place apart from the toto toilet, but they do tea well, they better I guess.
author: Michelle H.

description: Cool little place for a good change of pace from the everyday coffee shop. There are a good selection of tea and the prices are reasonable.
author: Keith S.

description:
Ahh. This was my favorite discovery during this last SF trip! When you enter into the establishment, the aroma of the boiling masala chai just takes over ... Which is GREAT. I geeked out about the different types of teas but I wish the cashier would have showed more enthusiasm about the menu! 

The teas are just plain teas. I highly recommend any of the speciality items. I got the masala chai, which was good but nothing extraordinary. I really liked my friend's turmeric latte. It was made on the spot and was very unique! Lines tend to be long but disappear quickly so be patient. Seats are limited but there's a parklet (yes that's a real word for mini park lol) right outside for you to enjoy your tea!
author: Lisa T.

description: The chai ... Just do yourself a favor and get it. Don't ask questions, just do it. I look forward to getting a cup anytime I'm in the area. They make the chai in large batches so it is nicely steeped when you get it. So good! The actual cafe doesn't have a ton of seating, but there's enough room if you just want to hang out and chat with a friend for a bit.
author: Cara R.

description: If you love tea you must visit this place. The space is lovely, the tea is divine and the mochi are the perfect treat to go with your tea. Their chai smells amazing, but I stick with oolong, white and black tea. All of it steeped perfectly.
author: Trisha D.

description: This place is delicious. I love tea and they have so many options. I tried the chai masala which you can sample and got the iced green tea matcha which was perfect for a hot day in the city.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Crisp, clean and bright is what attracted me to walk in here.  I didn't even know what this place was or what it sold.  My friends and I were just on our way to get ice cream, when we saw this place across the street.  We were drawn in when we saw the chai sign board outside on a cold, brisk night.  

This place has the art of tea making perfected.  Their high tech tea steeper made my husband think glorious things to buy when he wins the lottery.  Both of our teas were made at the exact right temperature and taste - optimal drinking temperatures with not a hint of over-brewing.  I felt very serene sipping my tea with my friends.

The other highlight of this place was the high tech bathroom.  It was so amusing trying to figure out how to use the handle bars in there.  Go check it out and you'll see what I mean.  

I hope I have more chances to stop by here for some excellent tea.  It's a little out of the way for me, but worth making a stop if I'm in the area.
author: Maria S.

description:
I'm very fond of this place, and go there quite often. The design is super minimalist and laid-back, and they play some trippy music that goes well with the tea. Also, the place smells very aromatic and herbal owing to all the brewing pots.

They have some really good teas - definitely some of the best matcha teas in the city. However, I mostly drink herbal teas, and the turmeric spice is my favorite there. They also have some great options for food - avocado toast, rice & greens, etc. if you're looking to eat too. You should definitely check out Samovar!
author: Pradyumn S.

description:
One word: aesthetics

A very simplistic cafe, which really attracted me about it. 

I got the Rosie Palmer. I was a bit iffy about it because it costed $4 and it was pretty small. However, once I tasted it, it's so refreshing and addicting. It has a delicious taste. It's sweet, but not extremely. I really enjoyed it and savored it. 

My friend got the green ecstasy. She really enjoyed her drink. You can really taste the matcha with the hint of grass. She thought the grass flavor was a nice touch to it, but I personally didn't love it. It is very refreshing, but I would choose the Rosie Palmer if I came back. 

Perfect place just to break out of the coffee norm and grab a cup of tea instead.
author: Amy T.

description: Great chai tea but it takes an incredibly long time to order, even when the line isn't that long. On multiple occassions, I've waited 20+ minutes in line when there were 3 people ahead of me. How long does it seriously take to take someone's tea order? I wouldn't be surprised if they purposefully take their time to give an illusion of a line out the door.
author: JB M.

description:
Love, love, love this place.

Got the standard chai tea and it definitely hit the spot.  
The interior of this place is a hitter and the workers are super friendly.  I wish they had one in SD.. I would come all the time.
author: Criselle O.

description: Stumbled upon Samover Tea while walking in the Mission and was drawn inside by the chill ambience and delicious smell of chai. They keep chai brewing in large copper pots, but also have an assortment of different teas (green, oolong, herbal, etc.). I also recommend trying the cute mochi cakes as they are a great addition to any tea/drink you may order. Overall I highly recommend stopping by -- I know I'll be back!
author: Raylene C.

description:
The avocado toast is the best in the city! It's great to hang out here an relax/reflect for a short break before carrying on your day. 

The vibes of the cafe are very mellow and the interior is beautiful. However there isn't a ton of seating and it's kinda quirky because the seats all directly face the counter, but not too bad! Just not the most ideal place to pop open a laptop and sit/work for a few hours. 

Get their chai! It's really really hot so don't burn your tongue, but definitely worth waiting for it to cool off a bit before you indulge in some delicious legit chai! 

I'm lucky my boyfriend's office is nearby so I pop by to visit for breakfast before I start my day :)
author: Jessica L.

description: It's sad they don't have a place like the one they had in Castro anymore. This one is just a small space, the only seating space is in a parklet outside. Not many choices on the menu.
author: Karla L.

description:
After walking past this little shop several times, my friend and I decided to stop in for a hot cup of tea on a cold day. We were lured in by the scent of chai spices, and though we kept going back and forth on what we wanted (because everything sounded amazing!), we both decided on the chai, since it seems like that's what Samovar is known for.

I was a little nervous because I'm usually not the biggest fan of chai, as it can sometimes get a little too spicy for my taste. What was interesting about this chai though, was that it grew on me the more I drank it. Other chai lattes I've tried normally get more and more spicy as I go through it, but Samovar's became gradually more pleasant. And with that, I think I've found my new favorite place for chai! 

On top of that, the shop itself is just beautiful. Highly recommend!
author: Sabrina C.

description:
Samovar Tea has just black , green, and ? teas listed. small space. just a bench or 2 for sitdown. ambience futuristic.

brew: jasimine (3.25)
-strong stuff, slight bitterness, fab stuff
-brewed in what is call a "crucible"
-tea better than most asian tea/boba places.

drips:
-tea brewed to order, took a few minutes.
author: Victor G.

description: The chai here is not as good/strong as it used to be when I first started coming in late 2015! And it's now VERY expensive. $6 for a large cup of TEA!?!  And almost $5 for mediocre toast with sweetened condensed coconut milk. Ridiculous. Won't be coming back.
author: Brooke F.

description:
They have a great selection of different teas, albeit other than teas, not much is noteworthy. The selection of pastries and desserts are limited and overpriced, although the presentation is cute.

Go in for the teas, stay for the atmosphere, and plan to lunch somewhere else.
author: Zorayr K.

description: I am still a fan of the chai but I'm really disappointed they got rid of the 6oz (small) chai size and their smallest is now 10oz at $5. It was really the perfect amount for me and anything more would have caused me to be too jittery off the sugar. Also there was one day when it was close to closing that the chai tasted super sugary and diluted and it was really disappointing. Other than that, it's still one of my go-tos for masala chai. Bring back the 6oz PLSSS!!
author: Ally L.

description: First time at Samovar and it was amazing! I had the Hong Kong Chai tea....it was fragrant, with the perfect amount of milk, smooth and DELICIOUS! I'll definitely be back! :)
author: Chase B.

description:
I'm not one to give perfect ratings to anything, but reflecting on the experience I had at Samovar's new tea bar earlier today there's literally only one single gripe I had and it's extremely minor. 

Positive side, the place has great decor -- very modern with hints of the rustic feel other samovars deliver. 

All the staff I dealt with we're friendly and smiley. 

They use Alpha Dominche steampunk brew machines which are as fascinating to watch as they are wonderful at brewing an ace cup of tea. I ordered an Iced Green Ecstasy which is a Japanese Sencha and it came out excellent -- bright green color, no astringency, yet still had that grassy flavor that I love about Sencha. Very refreshing. 

I'm curious to see how consistent the quality is, because other tea places vary from day to day and from staff to staff. I imagine the Steampunks they use eliminate most human error (it's app controlled) so I have high hopes. 

The single thing that bothered me was a lack of a bigger serving. Granted, tea is an experience to be savored, not devoured like some venti Starbucks nonsense, but I frequent David's tea daily by my work and receive larger servings for the same price. 

I guess they could have a bigger menu too, but I think they hit all the important spots with solid options. 

I will return here. Probably tomorrow morning for another iced Sencha.
author: Zac C.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE This place....Had masala chai  in this beautiful zen garden-like center near a large water sculpture. The service was friendly. The duck sandwich was delicious!
Enjoyed the peaceful time away from the city noise...
author: Kei D.

description: I had two good experiences and one not so good one. I always get their Chai with almond milk because it is really good and I don't like to have dairy. It is pricey which is why I look out one star. But during my last trip I brought my own tumbler to save a cup. Usually when i order tea/coffee anywhere else they away charge me for a smaller size. Not here. The women at the register poured the Chai in my tumbler and looked for the size, then I told her I'm not sure how many oz it holds. Then she pours it back out into a paper cup and charged me for the large which is accurate but so unnecessary. And it defeats the purpose of trying to save a cup. It would have been nice if she clarified how much i wanted in the beginning. Ah! which it why I took off another star.
author: Janet L.

description: Remarkable place! Surely it is worth descending there! Wonderful girls not just will allow you to drink tea, and will ship you in the real tea state!
author: Camilla R.

description:
This was my 1st time visiting this location. 
I love it! Great Chai for a very cold day. Enjoyed their pastry, too. I like this 'to go' tea shot place.
author: Pat S.

description:
This my first time at this location. I have been to Samovar Tea Lounge several times before and it is amazing. I was really excited to be walking by this new location and wanted to go in immediately. I got the chai tea with almond milk and it was pretty good (it tasted different then I remembered). 

My problem was when I bought the package of tea to take home. I asked the fello at the  counter to tell me where the packaged chai tea was and he told me it would be called "Masala Chai black." I bought it, $17 is pretty steep for tea but I had had this tea (or so I thought) at the tea lounge and thought it would be worth it. Long story short, it was not the same tea. The chai tea at the lounge is powdered and this came in loose leaves. I was so bummed when I figured this out. 

I feel like this should be something the barista should now right? Either there are multiple chai tea packages or that that option is not sold at this location. (espically since I mentioned that I loved this tea because I had tried it at the lounge) It didn't help that the chai tea I ordered came from a pot that contained pre-mixed tea in it (similar to the tea at the lounge. It does not come in loose leaves it comes pre-mixed in a mug). I may have notice I was getting a different chai tea hadn't that happened. 

I normally would sweep this under the rug but this 4oz tea package was $17 and it wasn't what I wanted. It was really disappointing.
author: Raquel H.

description:
Clean, crisp and pure - everything you want in a good cup of tea. The ambiance is the perfect compliment, and really sets you up to anticipate your crafted brew. 
The only caution I would give is that the teas are distinctive, and if you're not familiar you may find you either love or hate your choice. It just depends on your predisposition, your background and prejudices. 
The politics of tea are infinitely nuanced.
If you're a lover of sweet snacks to partner with your tea - the selection is limited and by mid afternoon you may find your favourites have all been snatched.
author: Andrea F.

description: Ive only been to the Yerba Buena locale so I dont know if they all have their own character or not. This one is certainly worlds different from that one. A stark white interior, with most the employees dressed in white aprons (is it just me or are the employees all fairly good looking, especially the blond in black?). Got a black tea, the Rosie's iced and even while we were sitting on the bench outside, employees gave us samples of what they were brewing. I wish they had more traditional seating but it's still a cool place regardless. 4.3 stars
author: Kim N.

description: Literally the most delicious chai tea I've ever had. Every person there is super sweet. The woman at the register took her time talking about what they served. Super friendly and helpful. They took "a little long" to make my avocado toast (it was like 2 minutes lol), but they still offered to add something for free. This place is amazing
author: Ricardo H.

description:
Parked in front of this place I didn't know was there in order to peruse the bikes across the street... Have heard of it, however.

Can mark it off my list. Just had a scalding Chai. No reason in the world for a tea to be scalding. Had trouble holding the cup, not to mention it took over a half hour to sip. Jesus, train your employees. Almost returned it, but it would have disturbed your cool vibe.
author: Elizabeth Q.

description: The avocado toast is absolutely delicious. Great flavor, nice portion. The vibe is laid back. The service professional and prompt. I had an iced chai too which was very flavorful.
author: April C. T.

description: Good tea bad humans- I'll explain. My partner and I went to this Samovar location. The people working there barely looked either of us in the face and the cashier woman actually couldn't be bothered to the point where I tried to ask her something and she directed me to the guy making the drinks. It's such a different vibe from the other Samovar! I can see it being more of a trend with the urban elite teenagers that want the vibe of an Urban Outfitters, aesthetic natural and stone interior and employees instructed not to engage with you. I can't emphasize that enough. My partner felt uncomfortable, being the only non-white person in the store. Needless to say I'm going to real tea stores from now on. The tumeric coconut latte is good but very easily made at home. It does offer gf bakery items. The place for you if all your food needs to be instagramable.
author: Peyton F.

description: Excellent chai tea! We ordered breakfast toast with avocado. It was just wonderful. Atmosphere made us feel relaxed in the morning. Very chic little place! Highly recommended!
author: Tomoe S.

description:
I like this place. I think it's fun and pretty darn neat. Whenever I'm in the area, I make it a point to come here. Even if tea isn't your thing, they have other items (drinks and food) on the menu. Not to mention, their set-up and lab display is awesome. 

I've gotten the classic chai but it's nothing I get excited about. If you're a true chai fan though, their spicier chai might make you fall in love. I usually just opt for their black or herbal teas which are always just as unique and delicious.

There is some seating but not really a place to hang out in. Cool place to drop in on a cold/ rainy day and impress your friends/family. Workers are friendly, helpful, and knowledgable.
author: Josselin A.

description:
Love that they have the vegan version of the chai tea! Delicioussss!! 
The decoration is to die for!
author: Andrea N.

description: The egg jar was definitely tasty, as was my green tea cortado. I also appreciated that you could sample the tea.  However,  this place mostly left me feeling like I'd paid too much money,  or, rather,  that I was paying mostly for the hipster contemporary minimalist upscale feel, that,  while upscale,  didn't include comfortable seating (hard concrete benches inset into the wall).
author: Jennifer O.

description: I am not a regular chai drinker, but theirs is so good, I stop in anytime I'm in the neighborhood. I've been to other Samovar locations and this is the only one I keep going back to, strictly for the chai.
author: Sloane F.

description:
i really want to love samovar. i work and live less than a half block away.
the mocha tea cakes are top notch.

when they get your order right, their matcha lattes are so legit.

unfortunately, if you have dietary allergies (to MILK) and order an almond milk matcha latte there's a high chance you'll leave sick. 

first time, fine. mistakes happen. i get it. (i'm sick, i'll deal with it)
** waits 2 months **
second time, again?! (goes back to work sick)

the staff is super friendly, but i can't in good conscious recommend this place to anyone with any type of allergy. they'll fuck your shit up.
author: Samantha C.

description: I love Samovar's Masala Chai, but I am sick of their tea being so scalding hot. It's one thing to use hot water, it is another to make it so so hot it melts the lid of the cup. This is dangerous and they really need to fix this problem.
author: Anastasia J.

description: I used to adore the masala chai at the Castro location, and the outdoor seating at Yerba Buena is nice. I used to regularly give their loose leaf tea as gifts. I have found the quality of the Mission location, though, to be a little inconsistent. This place is always crowded. I've gone in a little before closing and gotten a chai that wasn't very hot. I stopped by again last week, and they had just added the milk/cream to the pot before serving. It wasn't quite as strong and spicy as I'm used to, and tasted heavy on the milk. Not sure if that was because it was not stirred completely, or just hadn't brewed long enough. The cooper vats of the chai are charming, but with their pricing, I expect something more consistently delicious.
author: M T.

description:
This pretty cool tea lounge is heaven for chai tea lovers. Along with other teas, such as matcha, they handcraft their drinks to perfection. I heard the chai tea was popular so I had to order one during my first visit. It was delicious. It had various notes of spices and it was warm and comforting. You can also have it with whole milk or almond milk.

One star off for the awkward bench seating. There's no place to really sit and enjoy your beverage or pastries at a table with a friend. With such a cool interior, they should definitely make room for a table or two.
author: Laura T.

description: Workers here are knowledgeable and super friendly. My friend wanted coffee (Four Barrel, a block down), but I'm not an avid coffee enthusiast and I LOVE Chai so it was a great alternative. I opted for the iced chai with almond milk and it was delicious. Open, bright, and clean space with some seating if you'd like to chill for a bit. 4-5 tea samples as well (help yourself!)
author: Emily C.

description:
5 stars for their iced tea. So nice I had it twice (in the span of an hour).

Black tea + rose water + simple syrup + lemon juice= the Rosie Palmer. So refreshing and delightful. 

Pro tip: it's pretty sweet, so add an ounce of water to it to loosen it up. 

Can't speak to the other teas, but this was the best iced tea I've ever had. Holy crap. Definitely coming back to throw my dollars at them.

The good: iced tea like woah.
The bad: 'twas $4. Worth it.
author: Amanda B.

description: A friend and I stumbled across this place a couple months ago and instantly fell in love with the drinks. Although the food/snacks they have there have a high price point--we think this treat is worth it! This is also my favorite location! Easy to fall in love with this place.
author: Amy N.

description:
You're drawn to the smell of chai from down the street.
You see the beautiful beard of a worker from the window.
But you stay because the tea is damn good.

That's pretty much all I can say about this place. There are so many coffee places nearby but I'm more of a tea drinker. I LOVED the Ryokucha, it was the perfect green tea for the morning. The chai here is NOTHING like the Chai at Starbucks just by the way. Prepare your body for some real quality chai and tea. 

Pricey but you definitely pay for qualiTEA.
author: Dor H.

description: I stayed a short walk from Samovar during a quick trip to San Francisco, and I still miss it. The honey toast is a dream, and the matcha is prepared as it should be and is of excellent quality. The chai is also incredible.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Over priced tea in a Korean spa like setting 
Pretensions run high as the price of a cup of tea is $12.00 -pass on this rip off
author: Robert S.

description: It's always nice to get a wonderful cup of tea and sit and chat with friends or just relax and unwind and read your book.  Except there is NO place to sit.  What is the point of that?!?
author: Kamael S.

description:
I was told by the blonde guy that I couldn't have a large tea because the crucible is only calibrated for the small size. After this statement, he turned around and made my tea without the crucible. When I asked, he told me the crucibles were all out of order. ... ...

I walked down the street, saw my friend that had just gotten tea from Samovar 5 minutes before. FYI, they gave her a large.

1 star because they gave me a false excuse while not being consistent with their messaging and customer service.
author: Jonathan M.

description: Every time I walk by this place I tell myself I will stop in as the aromas that flood your senses take over you as you pass by. Well today was the day. Best chai (vegan - almond milk instead of whole) I've ever had. Yum!
author: Rachael S.

description:
Customer service: 0/5
Tea & food: 5/5 
I came here yesterday afternoon with my friend since she raved so much about the egg jar here. And when I try a new place out that i'm excited for, I want to expect to have at least a decent experience here. We walked inside super excited, knew what we wanted, and all you see are the 4 workers with literally no facial expressions. Just 4 blank, emptied faces. We were ready to order so we waited until one of the workers noticed us. The one blonde woman working there came up behind the tea bar and did not even say a thing. She stared at my friend  expecting her to just say her order and when she dis, she then just looked over at me and said nothing. Assuming she was going to take my order too, i happily said my order and all she said was "sure" blatantly and quickly turned over. HOW FREAKIN RUDE CAN YOU POSSIBLY BE. We thought maybe it was just her that was having a bad day, so one of the other workers rang up our order and he also had no expression on his face. It was a nice cute tea place with crappy faceless workers. My friend and I ended up tipping them both cause we just figured out of consideration to them having a bad day. As we wait for our food, my friend sees that the lady has made our food and put it on top of the counter w/o saying whether it was ours or not. She goes to the back, comes back, and my friends decides to ask if it is our food, the worker said yes without even looking up or acknowledging her whatsoever. She then asked my friend if we need utensils with her monotone voice, WITHOUT looking up still and pouring her freakin tea. When my friend says yes, she looks up at her  like this, -__-  and also asks, "to go?". WELL NO FREAKIN SHIT, we have food in jars, of course we're getting it to go. Not only was it just their attitude, but their diligence in just putting an effort into serving us. The worker leaves the bar, brushes past by me and does not even apologize, she literally drags her feet not trying to find utensils for us fast enough. Instead, she's moping around, SLOWLY BUT SURELY finding us some utensils. After that, Right when we are 5 ft away from leaving, one of the guys just suddenly got happy and wishes us a nice day. AND WE SAW THE ONLY LADY WORKER LAUGHING AND BEING FLIRTATIOUS AFTER WE LEFT. IT WAS SO UPSETTING TO HAVE SUCH A HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE THERE. Yes, their chai tea and food in a jar was good; although she was being skimpy on the salmon. But customer service really matters to me esp if it's your first time somewhere. Do not tip these guys if you walk in with expressionless workers there. Don't even acknowledge them if they can't even acknowledge you.
author: Stephanie H.

description: The design aesthetic of the cafe is remarkable and creates the perfect ambiance to relax and enjoy some of their high quality teas. I definitely recommend their Chai as well as any of their toasts or egg bowls. It's a shame the space wasn't larger, it's designed as more of grab and go place although there's some room if you choose to stay.
author: Bill H.

description: If you claim you are a tea shop, you should at least know how to properly steep the most basic cup of tea. I had ordered a Wulu green tea, which took 10 minutes. I'm sure they use loose leaf tea, and if you have high quality loose leaf tea and know how to actually brew tea, brewing takes no more than a few seconds. My friend had ordered a green tea matcha shake, which came out nearly immediately. After 5 minutes of waiting, I inquired the whereabouts of my green tea, of which the worker replied that it was still steeping. I watched my cup sit there on the back counter for at least another 4 minutes "steeping." Finally, the timer goes off. I go over to pick up my cup of tea, and as soon as I tasted it, I knew it was over-steeped because it was simply too tannic. I'm sure Samovar has other great drinks given their good reviews, and maybe one day I'll happen to be in the area and might stop in to try them, but as it stands now, when it comes to the basics of tea, this shop has no handle on it.
author: Alexis Y.

description: Stumbled in here while babysitting. Amazingly balanced and delish chai. Tea and pastries only. Not much seating (a few benches) but would definitely come back.
author: Aly S.

description: Fantastic little place with great food and great drinks. We stumbled on this place and so happy we did.
author: Adrian K.

description: Three stars for decent tea. But this is not your grab and go tea counter (nor is it a place to sit and relax-- no proper seating area!) the take so long to move through a line on top of the necessary steeping time for each tea. Samovar needs to work on efficiency and staff training of of this location. I won't come back after several good faith attempts. Too long to get a tea and no where to enjoy it even if you do have some free time.
author: Sarah E.

description:
best. chai. ever. [heart eyes emoji]

The aesthetics of this place also tops any tea shop I've visited. Although the shop is quite small, the minimalistic design gives the whole place an expanded feel. I also think the concrete benches on the side of the wall was a smart idea and adds a nice touch considering how small the space is.

A cup of chai tea is on the pricey side, but for the flavors and spices, it was so worth it. I also thought the cup itself was a substantial amount and I was able to split it with someone without feeling like I didn't have enough of it, oddly enough. I would definitely go back and try the other menu items like the green ecstasy and the rosie palmer. Customer service was great and friendly.
author: Christina C.

description: That chai was definitely not worth $4. This place is trendy, and the only tea spot around from what I could see. For that reason I gave it 3 stars, because of the lack of alternatives in the area.
author: C. D.

description: 5 stars might be a preemptive considering I've only been to this Samovar location once. However, I would definitely recommend this place for anyone who likes tea, especially green tea, which is rarely served at coffee shops. I've never been satisfied with the teas that are offered at coffee shops (like Four Barrel which is nearby), so Samovar was very refreshing. I tried the Ryokucha, which I'm pretty sure was a type of Genmaicha (sencha green tea, roasted brown rice, and matcha). Delicious. The service was great and I really liked how the set up of the shop makes it very easy to watch the baristas make the tea.
author: Tal M.

description:
Came here with a group of friends after dinner one night in the Mission. First of all, the ambience is not to be missed, even though it feels a little like gentrified India. It's warm and inviting; a great place to sit and chat with friends.

The tea: so many varieties to choose from! I had an herbal tea, Turmeric Spice. It tasted amazing and felt detoxifying. If you like tea with a little kick, this is for you. It came in it's own french press, which was big enough to be shared between two people (two cups each). My friend got the Spearmint Sage tea, which was on the lighter side and very refreshing.

I didn't have a chance to sample the food, but noticed that they had a few vegan options (that wasn't either a salad or veggie burger). Highly recommend.
author: Kelly L.

description: One of my favorite coffee/tea places in San Francisco. The baristas there are always so welcoming and warm any time of the day. I've been here countless times and they have never ever disappointed me. Their black tea is always perfection and they offer all kinds of condiments for your caffeine fix. Also, the aesthetic is perfection (imo) and I just love this place so much. Cannot recommend enough.
author: Kyle D.

description: Was in the Mission and recalled that Samovar opened a tea bar in the area. We came in to hide from the crazy wind and it was fairly empty. They have some interesting machines to make your tea. I had the GREEN ECSTASY and it was absolutely fantastic. Because this was my first time here, I asked about the Hong Kong Latte and Rosie Palmer, which they have pre-made, so they gave me a little sample of it. They also made the Hong Kong Latte for some of us to try. The service and staff are absolutely amazing, and the teas are delicious. I love that the decor is very minimal.
author: Liliana P.

description:
Vegan chai, sea salt chocolate chip cookies, turmeric spice herbal tea... my go to Samo orders. Everything is so fragrant and well-balanced. 

The staff (brianna, jose, victor, lady with purple hair) make my day better. 

Samo is a Valencia staple.
author: Em C.

description:
The chai smells cloyingly delicious, and tastes delicious, inside this spartanly-decorated, monochromatic little shop. I like how the brew is ladled from one of four brass-colored urns on the countertop into a clay mug, burned milk skim floating to the top. There are also implements that look like mad-scientist equipment bubbling away making other sorts of tea, of which this Samovar offers but a scant few in comparison to other locations. 
The shop is small, but has a few tiers of amphitheater-style seating along one wall, and a narrow bench along the outside façade. I suppose this arrangement sends laptop users away somewhere else, which is refreshing: one person reading a book while I was there, everybody else chatting or street-watching. 

I didn't much care for the sickly, fragile sort of sensitive rock and roll playing through the speakers; nor for the fact that the counter worker wore such a sad-sack countenance when good-naturedly greeted by person after person. Learn how to fake it, at least! Otherwise, this tea shop poses a nice alternative to the madhouse coffee-slinger up the block.
author: Brian G.

description: It's an experience. The tea-making contraptions are very cool to watch in use. Masala Chai was delicious, authentic. There isn't much room inside, but standing is an option. They also need more bathrooms.
author: Shu J.

description:
Good tea but expensive. $4.25 for a 12-ounce cup. The staff seemed very knowledgable. I'm not a tea drinker and they humored all of my questions and helped me settle on a very accessible Chai, which was spicy and not too sweet.

They have other locations where you can do flights and taste several teas at once. You can taste whatever they have brewing but this location doesn't offer the flight option.
author: Andrew S.

description: CLOSED: I drove by this Samovar this morning and the windows were papered over. I think this location has officially closed and new bakery is moving in. It was a good (crazy expensive) staple of the neighborhood, though.
author: Alexis W.

description:
What a beautiful and relaxing little place! We stopped in right before they were closing but the lovely lady with the lavendar hair at the register couldn't have been any nicer or more helpful. Instead of rushing us out, she gave us samples and answered all my questions. We even got a free pastry with the purchase of a cup of tea.

I'm fascinated by the design. You wouldn't think a minimualist space with concrete slabs for seating would be comfortable but it really is! I think it's because the lighting is soft with plenty of open space near the register and the menu is not full of an overwhelming amount of choices...an introvert's dream while still being inviting to those want to hang with friends.

What drew us in was the amazing smell of chai wafting down the sidewalk. Let's face it, usually the streets of the mission are not  something you want to inhale too deeply! So it was a pleasant surprise. In fact the woman ahead of us in the line couldn't contain her excitement as she exclaimed it "smells just like fall"! 

Who can resist the big copper pots simmering with every kind of chai imaginable (vegan, regular, pumpkin)? I only wish they had sugar-free version (they do have a caffeine free substitute that is sugar free but it's not made in the pots with milk).

I'll definitely be back!
author: Kristy O.

description:
Such a great little tea place. Unlike the other Samovar establishments, they serve ONLY TEA and some PASTRIES, and they make it to perfection.  It's a smaller place, good for to-go orders. The menu options are only CHAI, MATCHA, and black, green, or herbal tea.  We got the Vegan Chai Latte and Matcha Latte.  

Their chai is spicy, and the matcha latte is not sweet - just the way I like it.  

They have several high tech tea making contraptions that are fascinating to watch.  I love the design of the space too. Will definitely be back with friends.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Hong Kong Chai Tea?! 
I had to try it. It was earl gray and honey and whole milk and I can't remember what else but it came out to be a fragrant taste that was light and tasty. 

The space is beautiful, modern, simple, museum-istic in a way and zen feeling. This is not a place to linger for a long time as the seating is against the wall.

The hand dryer in the bathroom blew my mind.
author: Emily C.

description: It's only OK for me. The ambience was nice, the design well done, and the employees were very helpful. Very clean place. -2 stars for the price of their drinks for a small mostly ice beverage. Their honey was hardened and the lack of tables was a little bit of a disappointment. Otherwise if you happened to be in the neighborhood and want a quick bite and or quick drink this place will more than satisfy.
author: Gemini M.

description: I have to say, it is the best chai latte I've ever had. My usual order is a traditional chai latte with almond milk. I was a bit worried when I saw the large pot from which they ladled out some brown milky liquid. However, I was a believer at first sip. It has just enough spice, sweet, and creamy texture.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Love their green tea called green ecstasy! It does not need much or any sweetness but I added honey. Very good and warms you up. Teas are made to order. I sampled their chai and ocean wisdom teas and I enjoyed both. Chai was strong on ginger.
author: Foodie A.

description:
I wandered into Samovar today looking for a nice cup of tea.  I don't know much about their teas and they had a lot of options, so it took me a while to decide! I had the chai tea today (with milk) which was the perfect thing to drink. The chai tea is spicy and fresh, it tastes so much better than the chai you would get at a standard coffee shop. 

The cool thing about this location is that you can try a lot of the teas if you are unsure of what to order. A lot of the teas are brewed in batches, so it doesn't hurt to ask for a sample. The chai tea comes normal (with whole milk) or vegan (almond milk) and it is presweetened, but not too sweet. I'm used to black coffee and tea and I felt the sweet and spicy amounts were spot on. I didn't have a chance to try the pastries, but they looked fresh and delicious.

I love this grab and go location, but I wish there was still some seating other than a small bench in the back. This would otherwise be a great place to bring a book to!
author: Lauren G.

description: I like my Spearmint & Sage tea. All is fine and delicate Sure you must visit and try this place
author: Anne P.

description:
Enjoyed masala chai tea served instantly from a hot brewing vessel.It was a blend of teas and spices, with almond milk lightly sweetened, and prepared with steamed milk.I had it to go.The lid was very weak and flimsy - of poor quality. It spilled all over by the time I drove and reached home.Horrible customer experience.

I also went for some dessert - ordered the bostock which was large in size but ok in taste.
author: Priyanka L.

description: The first thing you notice when you enter this place is the zen like decor, the wonderful aroma of the spices in the chai teas brewing in huge copper cauldrons - you can't help but walk out with some wonderful whole milk or almond milk chai. The rest of the options of tea are wonderful as well. I also tried the turmeric tea which I think needs to be refined a little but not bad over all. I would definitely be coming back here again.
author: Zarlakhta W.

description: I work just down the street so I always swing by before work, on breaks, or on lunch! I love grabbing the usual - avocado toast (the oil and salt they use is to die for) and a masala chai. It's spicy and sweet and is always piping hot which I love. So much love for this place, perhaps my favorite tea joint!
author: Sharon Y.

description:
I was in town and had a couple of hours to kill before my flight home. Randomly walked past this place and decided I might as well give it a try seeing as I like my chai and usually make it myself. Jeez, was I disappointed. The guy who took my order turned his back to me mid-sentence, it took a new person a moment to realize I was standing at the counter ready to order. He took over, not apologizing. The phone rang, which resulted in him also abruptly disappearing from me. At this point I was ready to walk away, when a girl in her mid-20s asked if I had been seen yet. I said I wasn't sure, she took my order and handed me my iced chai with almond milk. The tea and the almond milk were pre-mixed, with little flakes of (what I assume was) almond bits floating on top. At this point I didn't even care any more and just wanted to get out of there and enjoy the sunshine. 

Taste-wise it was okay. It was definitely more on the spicy side with lots and lots of pepper in it. I've had better.
author: Alex P.

description:
I'd imagine if there were tea rooms in heaven, they would like like this. 

I had an event to attend at Public Works, so naturally I bookmarked a few places in the vicinity that I wanted to check out beforehand.  Due to the length of time it took me to find parking (ah, the joys of SF) along with the few crazies that were roaming the streets (more joys of SF), I decided to keep my adventure short and sweet. I decided to check out Samovar for a quick beverage to warm me up, and boy did I make the right choice. 

I had bookmarked it on Yelp already so I had seen some photos, but photos don't do it any justice.  I was so in awe I didn't even remember to take any photos myself! Doh! If I could describe the place in one word it would be: pristine. All white everything, gorgeous glass contraptions to brew the tea in, and they even had samples of their green, black, and herbal teas to sample. 

The gentleman who helped me was super sweet and patient as I decided.  One huge plus that is hard to find in SF shops is that they had a restroom! Sweet relief.

I settled on the Traditional Masala Chai.  It was heavenly and just the right drink for the first week of fall.  Not too sweet, and a little more spice to it than your typical chai (less pumpkin pie tasting).  It's definitely not a place you sit and hang out (head to their larger Yerba Buena location for that), but I was on the go so I didn't mind at all. I enjoyed drinking it during my stroll through the crazies and back to Public Works (I made it safely and without incident). 

I'll be back!
author: Mariah M.

description:
I was walking down Valencia Street looking for a coffee shop, but Samovar pulled me in with the sweet, spicy smell of Chai, its intriguing minimalist decor, and the haunting synths of Lorde's "Ribs" playing through Bose speakers. 

I ordered a Masala Chai with whole milk. The piping hot drink was ladled into my cup and handed to me right away. Some might say they serve it too hot; it certainly left the tip of my tongue slightly scalded. But for me, the heat added to the wonderful intensity of the drink. A combination of spicy Chai, sugar and rich (slightly salty) milk overpowered my senses in the best way. Sipping it slowly in the white, understated interior of the shop, the drink got my full attention and appreciation. 

Samovar's Masala Chai is a delicacy and an experience. Don't pass this place by without giving it a try. Let the aroma and ambience draw you in. I'm glad I did.
author: Joshua M.

description: Love this place. I never get out to the mission but sometimes I get out and can't wait to order a mint tea. If you love Chai this is the spot. You can even order your chai with almond milk. $5 for tea but  who cares.
author: Monique F.

description:
The guy with broken fingers (vincent??) was generous and affable as we came in just a few minutes shy of closing.

Love for mission samovar. Theyre killing it here.
author: Bobby H.

description:
I was walking around the mission district and came across Samovar randomly. I had intents of coming here prior, however on the fly is always better!

As I walked in, I was welcomed by a beautiful, cooling, clean environment. Everything is neutral and it smells great. I noticed the only places to sit were along the wall and outside, which I didn't mind because I was alone, however may not be a great place to hold meetings.

The girls in the front were helpful as I was looking for something iced and refreshing. They let me try both iced drinks, both amazing. 

I ended up getting a Rose Palmer, which has the perfect amount of rose flavoring. I got my drink "for here" because I initially enjoyed their choice of jazz music, which caused me to want to stick around and added to a great experience!
author: Melissa C.

description: Their honey butter toast and white truffle eggs and avo toast is delish!! I like to add sugar to their almond chai latte and macha latte bc I like sweet drinks, they're good as is too
author: A M.

description:
Amazing and creative tea choices. The chai with almond milk was great! The matcha green tea was pretty good. My favorite by far was the herbal spice, which is an herbal tea with lemongrass, ginger, licorice root, and turmeric powder mixed in. 

Pros: Friendly staff and good tea. 

Cons: the atmosphere was really 'cold' and not very welcoming. White stone walls with little to no decorations. It's the kind of place I would grab my tea and move along. The energy does not invite guests to stick around... but the tea flavors would keep me coming back.
author: Jennifer M.

description: This is a really sweet, clean, and calming tea shop! I got the matcha latte with almond milk which was super soothing first thing in the morning. They have sample teas you can try while you wait for your drink and a little bit of inside seating as well as a nice bench right outside where you can relax and sip your tea.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Coworkers and I stumbled upon this new Samovar location after lunch, and it smelled so good that they couldn't resist. Call me crazy, but I think tea kind of sucks. I want to like it, but I just...don't. So, I was pleased to see they had chai, which is occasionally pretty good - and bonus, they even have vegan chai! It certainly fell into my category of "pretty good," which by anyone else's tea standards would surely be delightful.

The space is terrible for relaxing - I think there's just one bench along the back wall. This doesn't bother me since I work just around the corner. Anyway, it's strikingly beautiful inside. White walls, cool stonework, lovely woodwork, and absolutely gorgeous copper cookware.
author: Rachel M.

description: Samovar Tea is a great addition to Valencia! It is pretty new but every time I have been here, I have loved it! When you walk in, there is a great atmosphere around you. It's very modern and clean cut with a minimalistic charm. Samovar Tea has a great selection of different teas, and they are all very interesting. They also have a menu with egg dishes and selections of pastries and desserts. I have not tried anything but their Traditional Masala Chai. Both times has been amazing. I enjoy the spice it has and you cannot go wrong with it! I would definitely come back here every chance I get! Next time I am curious to try to egg dishes they serve.
author: Emmanuella Z.
